articles.title: JUNE 1985
articles.summary: This article outlines the June and early July 1985 schedule for an astronomy club, featuring a general meeting, indoor star parties, observing expeditions, and a board meeting, culminating in major star parties at Yosemite and Fremont Peak. Additionally, it includes a 'Deep Sky Notes' column by Steve Gottlieb, offering a detailed observing guide for the spiral galaxy M101, complete with location tips, visibility descriptions, and telescopic views.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: This article provides an update on the status and location of several club telescopes, listing contact information for members holding the 14" Dobson and 6" telescopes for others to use. It also issues a call for assistance in locating two missing SJAA telescopes: a 12" refractor and a 2.4" refractor.

articles.title: YOSEMITE TRIP
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming Yosemite Star Party scheduled for July 12th and 13th, reminding interested individuals to sign up soon. Participants need to contact Jim Van Nuland with details about their party size and vehicles to facilitate campsite reservations by SJAA staff.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP RENEWALS
articles.summary: SJAA members are reminded to renew their subscriptions by sending renewal cards from Sky and Telescope Magazine and checks payable to SJAA to Bob Fingerhut at the provided Milpitas address. Failure to renew by the end of June will result in the loss of Sky and Telescope subscriptions and issues of the Ephemeris.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL AUCTION SUCCESS
articles.summary: The SJAA successfully held its 5th annual Astronomical Auction on May 11th, attracting 150 attendees who bid on items from Space Shuttle tiles to telescopes. The event generated over $500 for operational costs and observatory sales, with many larger items selling unexpectedly well. The auction ran smoothly due to pre-registration and functioning computers, attracting many new faces who had previously visited the SJAA's Astronomy Day display.

articles.title: CID CAMERA
articles.summary: Bruce de Graaf is seeking assistance from 'Astro Hackers' to get a new CID Camera, replacing a stolen unit, properly functioning with a television monitor, and plans to release more information soon. The document also provides a detailed guide on observing and sketching faint astronomical knots, referencing specific NGC objects (5447, 5462, 5455, 5445) and comparing modern observations with historical records like Burnham's CELESTIAL HANDBOOK and Rosse's 1851 sketch.

articles.title: SJAA GETS TAX EXEMPT STATUS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) has finally received its tax-exempt status after 30 years. This new status means that the EPHEMERIS newsletter will be mailed under non-profit rates, and all membership dues and contributions to the SJAA are now fully tax-deductible. The organization is encouraging donations.

articles.title: PARDON MY TYPO
articles.summary: The author expresses gratitude for positive feedback on the May EPHEMERIS, noting that the newsletter's production is becoming more stable, with typographic and spelling errors being the primary remaining challenge. This current issue was produced entirely on a new Hewlett Packard 110 computer and ThinkJet printer, testing a new system in anticipation of potentially losing access to professional equipment. This change resulted in a slightly larger, easier-to-read print type.

articles.title: EQUIPMENT
articles.summary: This article discusses Celestron's potential 20" telescope and the author's concerns about portability and cost for such a large instrument. The author then provides several suggestions for improving Celestron's existing product line, focusing on mechanical refinements like the worm drive, fork arm stability, paint options for heat management, and more meaningful accessories, while praising their current optical quality and silver coatings.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article, 'COMET COMMENTS' by Don Machholz, reports on the recovery of three comets, noting a lower than usual total for the year. It details the recovery of Periodic Comet Russell 1 (1985b) and the unique amateur recovery of Periodic Comet Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova (1985c). The piece also provides an ephemeris and observing notes for Periodic Comet Giacobini-Zinner (1984e), mentioning its potential instability and connection to Giacobinid meteors, with a brief mention of Halley's Comet.

articles.title: COMET SHOEMAKER (1984F)
articles.summary: Comet Shoemaker (1984F) is currently visible in the evening sky, described as diffuse and 1-2 arcminutes in size, though its far southern position makes observation challenging. The article provides an ephemeris listing its celestial coordinates, elongation, and predicted magnitude (around 11.3-11.6) for late May through early July, encouraging observers to attempt to view it.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND - HALLEY'S
articles.summary: The article provides an update on Halley's Comet, detailing its current position near the sun, anticipated visibility in late July, and updated orbital elements. It also lists various booklets and handbooks for observers interested in the comet. Separately, an observing report from Calico Observatory describes a recent sighting of Jupiter's "Spot" under challenging conditions, noting its shape and encouraging reader contributions.

articles.title: Great Red Spot
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule of predicted transit times for Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) across the planet's central meridian. The table lists specific dates in June and July, along with corresponding times, including mentions of PDT, to aid in observing the GRS.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE
articles.summary: The Challenger shuttle successfully completed its Spacelab 3 mission, landing at Edwards AFB after extensive experimentation. The mission focused on materials and life science, with a notable achievement being the production of two large triglycine sulfate crystals for infrared detection, overcoming initial challenges.

articles.title: FOURTH SHUTTLE ORBITER DELIVERED
articles.summary: The fourth Space Shuttle Orbiter, Atlantis, was delivered to Kennedy Space Center on April 13th. Its inaugural launch is slated for September 26th.

articles.title: SPACELAB D1 DELIVERED MAY 1 FOR OCT. 16 LAUNCH
articles.summary: The Spacelab D1 mission, a dedicated German flight aboard the orbiter Columbia, was delivered on May 1 and is slated for an October 16 launch. It will host experiments across various scientific disciplines including botany, biology, medicine, materials science, and navigation.

articles.title: INFRARED TELESCOPE IN 747 SP PROPOSED
articles.summary: NASA has initiated a feasibility study to investigate the potential of integrating a 3.0-3.5 meter infrared telescope into a 747SP aircraft. This ambitious project aims to establish an airborne observatory, with a target operational date set for 1989.

articles.title: NASA - NOAA DISPUTE SETTLED
articles.summary: A dispute between NASA and NOAA regarding the launch of Tiros-N weather satellites has been settled. NOAA initially preferred Titan boosters, but the agreement mandates launches on the Space Shuttle, granting NASA full budget authority for these launches and modifications to NOAA's K, L, and M spacecraft. Additionally, NOAA will provide environmental remote sensing instruments for a polar orbiting platform to operate with the U.S. space station.

articles.title: SOUND SUPPRESSION SYSTEM TESTED AT VANDENBERG AFB
articles.summary: A sound suppression system underwent successful testing at Vandenberg AFB. The test involved the space shuttle orbiter Enterprise, which was stacked on the launch pad during the operation.

articles.title: MEDICAL HORMONE PRODUCED ON FLIGHT 51-D IN FLIGHT 51-D IN APRIL
articles.summary: An electrophoresis experiment on Space Shuttle Flight 51-D successfully processed 100% of its sample, producing an unidentified medical hormone. Enough of the hormone was created to begin testing, with a potential market release by 1988. McDonnell Douglas has requested a payload specialist for mission 51-B in November, which will utilize a new payload bay processing system.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The article outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) telescope loan program for its members and provides information on free astronomical want ads in their Ephemeris bulletin. It also details various scientific experiments conducted during a space flight, covering topics such as crystal growth, fluid dynamics, atmospheric chemistry, auroral observations, animal adaptation to zero-g, satellite deployment, and motion sickness research, often noting technical issues and partial successes encountered during these missions.

articles.title: IN ORBIT REPAIR OF LEASAT PLANNED
articles.summary: NASA has devised a plan for an in-orbit repair of a Leasat satellite during mission 51-I in August. The repair involves bypassing a sequencer and ordering the satellite to fire its booster to transfer to geosynchronous orbit, which will require a spacewalk. A second Leasat satellite is also scheduled for launch on the same mission.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY DAY
articles.summary: The SJAA successfully hosted an Astronomy Day display at Eastridge Shopping Mall in Cupertino, attracting nearly 500 people. The event featured various telescopes, a slide show, and astrophotography information, generating significant interest in astronomy and Halley's Comet, even among those previously unaware of the organization. Despite being held indoors for the first time, it was a huge success, with organizers hoping to see new faces at future meetings.

articles.title: CROWDED PEAK
articles.summary: The article reports on a large gathering of amateur astronomers at Fremont Peak State Park on May 18th, despite poor weather and observing conditions. It details various observations, including impressive views through a 16" telescope and a new 4" fluorite refractor, which is extensively compared to a 4" achromat. The piece also covers a technical issue with a Celestron C11 clock drive and the discovery that Celestron had adopted a design by one of the attendees.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document provides logistical details for the SJAA's general meetings and "Indoor Star Parties," which are held monthly at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. It includes the full address and detailed driving directions from Hwy 17 South, noting that meetings commence at 8 PM.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is highlighted as a popular observing site for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), providing detailed directions via Mt. Hamilton Road. The article includes crucial access information, such as a combination lock for the park gate (sequence 4565) and mentions an additional observing area further up the road. Users are reminded to re-lock the gate after use.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park, starting from Hwy 101 South near Gilroy, and includes instructions for accessing the park's observing site. It specifies the club gate combination, emphasizes locking the gate, and advises on parking procedures, especially when arriving after dark, to ensure a smooth and safe observing experience.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, specifically guiding visitors to Coulter Camp where the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) sets up. It includes turn-by-turn instructions from Hwy 101, a basic map, and a crucial reminder to use parking lights only after dark. The piece also identifies EPHEMERIS as a monthly publication of the SJAA.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, detailing the roles of President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. It provides their names, mailing addresses, and contact phone numbers for each position. Notably, Robert Fingerhut holds both the President and Treasurer roles.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document lists the members of the Board of Directors, including Paul Mancuso, Steve Greenberg, Tom Ahl, Gene Cisheros, Joe Sunseri, Chris Pratt, and Denni Medlock. Each director's name is accompanied by their respective phone number, providing direct contact information for the board.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS EDITOR:
articles.summary: This document introduces an 'Ephemeris Editor' tool, likely a software application designed for managing astronomical ephemerides. It provides contact details for its creator, John P. Gleason, including his address and phone number.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document serves as a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options and their corresponding fees. It outlines categories such as adult, junior, and memberships bundled with a Sky & Telescope subscription. The application also provides submission instructions, including mailing to the treasurer or bringing it to an SJAA meeting, along with contact information.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about an individual's astronomical interests (e.g., astrophotography, deep-sky observation, telescope making) and telescope ownership. It also asks if the respondent is qualified to assist others in specific areas of astronomy. The latter part of the document includes postal information for SJAA EPHEMERIS, indicating it's time-sensitive news material distributed via bulk rate.
